0.title: Snowden Is Said to Renew Plea for Asylum in Russia
0.summary: Edward J. Snowden met with representatives of human rights organizations at his temporary Moscow airport refuge on Friday and appealed for their help in seeking asylum status.

1.title: All-Stars of 1964 Recall a Wild Show at Shea
1.summary: On July 7, 1964, Johnny Callison’s ninth-inning homer decided the first All-Star Game hosted by the Mets. The rosters included 18 future Hall of Famers.

2.title: New Injury Halts Jeter’s Comeback
2.summary: General Manager Brian Cashman said the Yankees would re-evaluate Derek Jeter’s injury, a Grade 1 quadriceps strain, after the All-Star break. Jeter was hurt in his first game back from a twice-broken ankle.

3.title: Boeing 787 Catches Fire in London
3.summary: The incident, on a plane with no passengers aboard, took place about seven weeks after 787s returned to the skies after being grounded because of hazards with a new type of battery.

4.title: Napolitano Stepping Down as Homeland Security Chief
4.summary: Janet Napolitano, who has overseen an expansive portfolio as President Obama’s secretary of homeland security, plans to become president of the University of California system.

5.title: Sudden Spike in Gas Prices, but Increases May Be Short-Lived
5.summary: Gasoline prices have been rising, mainly because of higher global crude prices that have been gaining because of Egyptian and Nigerian unrest.

6.title: New York Times Names a New National Editor
6.summary: Alison Mitchell, the weekend editor of The Times, was named national editor to replace Sam Sifton, who will work on online projects.

7.title: Ideas to Bolster Power Grid Run Up Against the System’s Many Owners
7.summary: A fragmented system, with conflicting interests, poses hurdles for improvements that the past three presidents have called a priority.

8.title: Twitter Yields to Pressure in Hate Case in France
8.summary: Twitter has agreed to identify several users who posted anti-Semitic comments on its service, and whom French authorities are seeking to prosecute for violating that country’s anti-hate laws.

9.title: Amar G. Bose, Acoustic Engineer and Inventor, Dies at 83
9.summary: Dr. Bose’s namesake company became synonymous with high-quality audio systems and speakers for home users, auditoriums and automobiles.

10.title: Where Car Is King, Smartphones May Cut Traffic
10.summary: Transit experts say these new services could play a crucial role in ending the reign of single-occupant cars (and unending traffic) in Los Angeles.

11.title: Third Girl Aboard Asiana Jet Dies From Injuries
11.summary: A girl who was aboard the Asiana Airlines flight that crash-landed died Friday, the same day that authorities confirmed one of the two Chinese teenagers killed in the disaster was hit by a firetruck.

12.title: Cleveland Man Faces 648 More Charges in Abduction of Women
12.summary: Former Cleveland school bus driver Ariel Castro now faces 977 criminal charges stemming from the abduction and imprisonment of three women who were freed two months ago after a decade of captivity, as 648 new charges were added on Friday, prosecutors said.

13.title: At Least 6 Dead and Dozens Injured as Train Derails Near Paris
13.summary: Dozens of others were injured when a crowded passenger train went off the track entering a station in France’s worst train accident in 25 years.

14.title: Holder Tightens Rules on Getting Reporters’ Data
14.summary: The guidelines would make it harder for prosecutors to obtain journalists’ calling records from telephone companies without giving news organizations advance notice.

15.title: News Analysis: Testing the Consequences of Male Misbehavior
15.summary: Are women really outraged over the Spitzer and Weiner candidacies?

16.title: Blast in Northern Iraq City Kills 19, Officials Say
16.summary: Iraqi officials said a bomb exploded inside a crowded coffee shop in Kirkuk, wounding 26.

17.title: Texas Senate Begins Debate on Bill Restricting Abortions
17.summary: A vote for passage is expected soon on the bill, which would ban abortions after 20 weeks of pregnancy and impose new standards on clinics and doctors.

18.title: Author’s Views on Gay Marriage Fuel Call for Boycott
18.summary: A boycott campaign against the coming film “Ender’s Game,” prompted by the anti-gay views of the author of the novel that inspired the movie, has suddenly gained traction.

19.title: The Lede: Malala Yousafzai, Girl Shot by Taliban, Makes Appeal at U.N.
19.summary: On her 16th birthday, Malala Yousafzai spoke at the United Nations and called on world leaders to make education available and compulsory for every child.

20.title: Hardening Split in Egypt as Islamists Stage Huge Demonstrations
20.summary: The size of the protests underlined the large section of society that has rejected the military intervention that deposed President Mohamed Morsi.

21.title: Owners of Hulu Call Off Sale and Plan to Invest $750 Million
21.summary: The streaming-video Web site had been seeking bids for months. The owners — 21st Century Fox, the Walt Disney Company and NBCUniversal — instead decided not to sell.

22.title: Zimmerman Case Goes to Jury
22.summary: In closing arguments, the defense emphasized George Zimmerman’s fears for his own life and the deadly potential in a slab of concrete.

23.title: A Secret Food Satirist Comes Out of the Pantry
23.summary: The identity of @ruthbourdain, a Twitter avatar created to poke fun at the pretensions of the culinary elite, is revealed.

-1.title: In Some Parts of Egypt, Bad Times Remained Bad
-1.summary: In the impoverished Egyptian town of Fayoum, conditions never improved during Mohamed Morsi’s presidency and the future now seems unsettled and unpromising.
